introduction.p:
Recall that velocity \vec v is derivative of position \vec r. To emphasize that this definition is true at each instant t, let us write each vector with its dependence on time t.
\vec v(t) = \frac{d\vec r(t)}{dt}.
Now, we ask how can we get dispacement, i.e., change in position in an interval t=t_i to t=t_f? From Calculus, this is obtained by integrating both sides of this equation from t=t_i to t=t_f. Formally, the steps of calculation would go as follows.
\int_{t_i}^{t_f}\vec v(t) dt = \int_{t_i}^{t_f} \frac{d\vec r(t)}{dt} dt.
The canceling dt on the right side, gives integral over d\vec r, which leads to just change in position when integrated.
\int_{t_i}^{t_f} \frac{d\vec r(t)}{dt} dt = \int_{\vec r_i}^{\vec r_f} \frac{d\vec r(t)} = \vec r_f - \vec r_i.
That is, displacment in the time interval is given by the integration of the velocity vector over that interval.
\vec r_f - \vec r_i = \int_{t_i}^{t_f}\vec v(t) dt.

The components of this equation are related to integrating the components of the velocity.
\amp x_f - x_i = \int_{t_i}^{t_f}v_x(t) dt \amp y_f - y_i = \int_{t_i}^{t_f}v_y(t) dt \amp z_f - z_i = \int_{t_i}^{t_f}v_z(t) dt
In this form, since we are dealing with integration over ordinary functions, and nor a vector fuction of t, we can interpret the right sides of these component equations in terms of area under the curve or area above the curve in a plot of the correponding velocity component.

That is, if you plot v_x versus t, the right side of equation can be evaluated by the integration below the plot if v_x is positive in the time range and above the plot if v_x is negative with area now negative. The sum of all positive and negative areas in the interval will give \Delta x \equiv x_f - x_i. Similarly, for \Delta y and \Delta z.

example.title: Area Under the Velocity versus Time Plot
example.p:
To interpret Eqs. , let us look at a numerical example where v_x is constant. Then, integration gives
\int_{t_i}^{t_f}v_x(t) dt = v_x \int_{t_i}^{t_f} dt = v_x( t_f - t_i ) = v_x\, \Delta t.

sidebyside.p: Let v_{x} = 5\text{ m/s} and \Delta t = 2\text{ s}. Suppose we plot v_x versus t, then we will find that v_{x}\times {\Delta t} = 10 \text{ m} gives us the area under the v_x versus t plot, which is equal to change in x, \Delta x = 5\text{ m/s} \times 2\text{ s} = 10 \text{ m}.

If velocity v_x is negative during the interval, it would mean that object is moving towards negative x axis. This shows up as negative area above the plot. Therefore, the x displacement will be \Delta x = -5\text{ m/s} \times 2\text{ s} = - 10 \text{ m}.

example.title: Displacement from Velocity - Areas Under Curve

statement.p: shows a v_x versus t plot. Find the displacements in the following intervals, given in seconds, (a) (0,\ 4), (b) (4,\ 6), (c) (6,\ 8), (d) (8,\ 10), and (e) (0,\ 10).

sidebyside.p:
Note that the t axis is the v_x = 0 line. Therefore, we need the area of the shaded region in the figure on the right. This gives
\Delta x = \dfrac{1}{2}\times 2\text{ s} \times 2\text{ m/s} = 2\text{ m}.

Note that the t axis is the v_x = 0 line. Therefore, we need the area of the shaded region in the figure on the right. This area will be negative as is also clear from the direction motion - it is moving to the left. This gives
\Delta x \amp = \dfrac{1}{2}\times 2\text{ s} \times (-2\text{ m/s}) \amp = -2\text{ m}.

Note that the t axis is the v_x = 0 line. Therefore, we need the area of the shaded region in the figure on the right. This area will be negative as is also clear from the direction motion - it is moving to the left. This gives \Delta x \amp = 2\text{ s} \times (-2\text{ m/s}) \amp = -4\text{ m}.

solution.title: e
solution.p:
Adding up all the areas we get
\Delta x(0\rightarrow 10\text{ s}) = 8\text{ m} + 2\text{ m} + (-2)\text{ m} + (-4)\text{ m} = 4\text{ m}.

statement.p: A particle is moving in a circle with its velocity components changing with time as given by (in units of m/s with t in units of seconds.) v_x = 5.0\,\cos(2\pi t),\ \ \ v_y = 5.0\,\sin(2\pi t). (a) What are the components of the displacement vector during the interval from t=0.25\text{ s} to t=0.50\text{ s} . (b) What are the magnitude and direction of the displacement?

answer.p: (a) (-0.80\text{ m},\ 0.80\text{ m} ) (b) 1.13\text{ m} in 45^{\circ} direction from the negative x axis into the second quadrant.

solution.title: a
solution.p:
The components will be obtained by taking the integral.
\Delta x \amp = \int_{0.25}^{0.5}\, 5.0\,\cos(2\pi t)\, dt, \amp = \dfrac{5.0}{2\pi}\sin(2\pi t)|_{0.25}^{0.5} \amp = -0.80\text{ m}.
\Delta y \amp = \int_{0.25}^{0.5}\, 5.0\,\sin(2\pi t)\, dt, \amp = -\dfrac{5.0}{2\pi}\cos(2\pi t)|_{0.25}^{0.5} \amp = 0.80\text{ m}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
Therefore, the magnitude and angle will be:
\Delta r = 0.8\times \sqrt{2} = 1.13\text{ m}, \theta = \tan^{-1}(-1) = - 45^{\circ},
which we interpret to be clockwise angle of 45^{\circ} from the negative x axis into the second quadrant.
